hints.content: Start by understanding the concept of frequency of characters in the string. For example, in the string 'aabcaba', the frequencies are: 'a' -> 4, 'b' -> 1, 'c' -> 1.
Consider how to calculate the frequency of each character in the string. You can use a dictionary or an array of size 26 (for lowercase English letters) to store these frequencies.

Think about the condition for a string to be k-special: the absolute difference between the frequencies of any two characters must be less than or equal to k. This means you need to identify the maximum and minimum frequencies.
Once you have the frequencies, find the maximum frequency (max_freq) and the minimum frequency (min_freq). The goal is to ensure that the difference between these two frequencies does not exceed k.

If max_freq - min_freq > k, you will need to reduce frequencies. Consider how many characters you need to delete to bring the max frequency down or the min frequency up to satisfy the k-special condition.

Think about which characters to delete. It might be more efficient to reduce the frequency of the most frequent characters first, as this could yield a larger reduction in the overall frequency range.
As you calculate the deletions needed, keep track of the total number of deletions. You can maintain a count of how many characters you have deleted from each frequency.
Consider edge cases: What if k is 0? In this case, all characters must have the same frequency, which simplifies your approach. You will need to make all character frequencies equal.
If the string has only one unique character, it is already k-special for any k. Thus, no deletions are needed in this case.
To finalize your solution, ensure that you return the total number of deletions required to make the string k-special. This should be the minimum number of characters you need to delete.

questionNotes: The string consists only of lowercase English letters.
Return the total number of deletions needed to make the string k-special.
